The standard form of Mathieu’s equation with parameters (a,q) is w^{\prime\prime}+(a-2q\cos\left(2z\right))w=0.
With \zeta={\sin^{2}}z we obtain the algebraic form of Mathieu’s equation \zeta(1-\zeta)w^{\prime\prime}+\tfrac{1}{2}\left(1-2\zeta)w^{\prime}+\tfrac{1} {4}(a-2q(1-2\zeta)\right)w=0.
This equation has regular singularities at 0 and 1, both with exponents 0 and \frac{1}{2} , and an irregular singular point at \infty.
With \zeta=\cos z we obtain another algebraic form: (1-\zeta^{2})w^{\prime\prime}-\zeta w^{\prime}+\left(a+2q-4q\zeta^{2}\right)w=0.

subsection.title: Basic Solutions w_{\mbox{\rm\tiny I}}, w_{\mbox{\rm\tiny II}}

para.sentence: Since (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.Ma) has no finite singularities its solutions are entire functions of z.
Furthermore, a solution w with given initial constant values of w and w^{\prime} at a point z_{0} is an entire function of the three variables z , a , and q.

The following three transformations z\to-z;, z\to z\pm\pi;, z\to z\pm\tfrac{1}{2}\pi,q\to-q; each leave (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.Ma) unchanged. (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.Ma) possesses a fundamental pair of solutions w_{\mbox{\tiny I}}(z;a,q),w_{\mbox{\tiny II}}(z;a,q) called basic solutions with \begin{bmatrix}w_{\mbox{\tiny I}}(0;a,q)&w_{\mbox{\tiny II}}(0;a,q)\\ w^{\prime}_{\mbox{\tiny I}}(0;a,q)&w^{\prime}_{\mbox{\tiny II}}(0;a,q)\end{ bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}1&0\\ 0&1\end{bmatrix}.
w_{\mbox{\tiny I}}(z;a,q) is even and w_{\mbox{\tiny II}}(z;a,q) is odd.
Other properties are as follows.

subsection.title: Floquet’s Theorem and the Characteristic Exponents

para.sentence: Let \nu be any real or complex constant.

Then Mathieu’s equation (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.Ma) has a nontrivial solution w(z) such that w(z+\pi)=e^{\pi\mathrm{i}\nu}w(z), iff e^{\pi\mathrm{i}\nu} is an eigenvalue of the matrix \begin{bmatrix}w_{\mbox{\tiny I}}(\pi;a,q)&w_{\mbox{\tiny II}}(\pi;a,q)\\ w^{\prime}_{\mbox{\tiny I}}(\pi;a,q)&w^{\prime}_{\mbox{\tiny II}}(\pi;a,q)\end {bmatrix}.
Equivalently, \cos\left(\pi\nu\right)=w_{\mbox{\tiny I}}(\pi;a,q)=w_{\mbox{\tiny I}}(\pi;a,- q).
This is the characteristic equation of Mathieu’s equation (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.Ma).
\cos\left(\pi\nu\right) is an entire function of a,q^{2}.
The solutions of (LABEL:eq:MA.FE.C2) are given by \nu=\pi^{-1}\operatorname{arccos}\left(w_{\mbox{\tiny I}}(\pi;a,q)\right).
The general solution of (LABEL:eq:MA.FE.C2) is \nu=\pm\widehat{\nu}+2n , where n\in\mathbb{Z}.
Either \widehat{\nu} or \nu is called a characteristic exponent of (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.Ma).

If a nontrivial solution of Mathieu’s equation with q\neq 0 has period \pi or 2\pi , then any linearly independent solution cannot have either period.

Second solutions of (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.Ma) are given by \mathrm{fe}_{n}\left(z,q\right)=C_{n}(q)\left(z\mathrm{ce}_{n}\left(z,q\right) +f_{n}(z,q)\right), when a=a_{n}\left(q\right) , n=0,1,2,\dots , and by \mathrm{ge}_{n}\left(z,q\right)=S_{n}(q)\left(z\mathrm{se}_{n}\left(z,q\right) +g_{n}(z,q)\right), when a=b_{n}\left(q\right) , n=1,2,3,\dots.

For m=0,1,2,\dots , we have \begin{array}[]{ll}f_{2m}(z,q)&\mbox{$\pi$-periodic, odd},\\ f_{2m+1}(z,q)&\mbox{$\pi$-antiperiodic, odd},\end{array} and \begin{array}[]{ll}g_{2m+1}(z,q)&\mbox{$\pi$-antiperiodic, even},\\ g_{2m+2}(z,q)&\mbox{$\pi$-periodic, even};\end{array} compare §LABEL:sec:MA.LF.PF.
The functions f_{n}(z,q) , g_{n}(z,q) are unique.

The factors C_{n}(q) and S_{n}(q) in (LABEL:eq:MA.SE.D1) and (LABEL:eq:MA.SE.D2) are normalized so that (C_{n}(q))^{2}\int_{0}^{2\pi}(f_{n}(x,q))^{2}\mathrm{d}x=(S_{n}(q))^{2}\int_{0 }^{2\pi}(g_{n}(x,q))^{2}\mathrm{d}x=\pi.
As q\to 0 with n\neq 0 , C_{n}(q)\to 0 , S_{n}(q)\to 0 , C_{n}(q)f_{n}(z,q)\to\sin nz , and S_{n}(q)g_{n}(z,q)\to\cos nz.
This determines the signs of C_{n}(q) and S_{n}(q).

(Other normalizations for C_{n}(q) and S_{n}(q) can be found in the literature, but most formulas—including connection formulas—are unaffected since \mathrm{fe}_{n}\left(z,q\right)/C_{n}(q) and \mathrm{ge}_{n}\left(z,q\right)/S_{n}(q) are invariant.)

subsection.title: Discriminant and Eigenvalues in the Real Case

para.sentence: Q(x) is assumed to be real-valued throughout this subsection.
The function \bigtriangleup(\lambda)=w_{\mbox{\tiny I}}(\pi,\lambda)+w_{\mbox{\tiny II}}^{ \prime}(\pi,\lambda) is called the discriminant of (LABEL:eq:MA.HI.F.01).
It is an entire function of \lambda.
Its order of growth for |\lambda|\to\infty is exactly \tfrac{1}{2} ; see ( , Chapter II, pp. 19–28) .
For a given \nu , the characteristic equation \bigtriangleup(\lambda)-2\cos\left(\pi\nu\right)=0 has infinitely many roots \lambda.
Conversely, for a given \lambda , the value of \bigtriangleup(\lambda) is needed for the computation of \nu.
For this purpose the discriminant can be expressed as an infinite determinant involving the Fourier coefficients of Q(x) ; see ( , §2.3, pp. 28–36) .

To every equation (LABEL:eq:MA.HI.F.01), there belong two increasing infinite sequences of real eigenvalues: \lambda_{n},\;n=0,1,2,\dots,\mbox{ with $\bigtriangleup(\lambda_{n})=2$}, , \mu_{n},\;n=1,2,3,\dots,\mbox{ with $\bigtriangleup(\mu_{n})=-2$}.
In consequence, (LABEL:eq:MA.HI.F.01) has a solution of period \pi iff \lambda=\lambda_{n} , and a solution of period 2\pi iff \lambda=\mu_{n}.

Both \lambda_{n} and \mu_{n}\to\infty as n\to\infty , and interlaceaccording to the inequalities \lambda_{0}<\mu_{1}\leq\mu_{2}<\lambda_{1}\leq\lambda_{2}<\mu_{3}\leq\mu_{4}< \lambda_{3}\leq\lambda_{4}<\cdots.

For m_{1}\neq m_{2} , \int_{0}^{2\pi}\mathit{hc}_{p}^{m_{1}}(x,\xi)\mathit{hc}_{p}^{m_{2}}(x,\xi) \mathrm{d}x=\int_{0}^{2\pi}\mathit{hs}_{p}^{m_{1}}(x,\xi)\mathit{hs}_{p}^{m_{2 }}(x,\xi)\mathrm{d}x=0.

For \xi>0 , the functions \mathit{hc}_{p}^{m}(z,\xi) , \mathit{hs}_{p}^{m}(z,\xi) behave asymptotically as multiples of \exp\left(-\tfrac{1}{4}\xi\cos\left(2z\right)\right)\left(\cos z\right)^{p} as z\to\pm\mathrm{i}\infty.

subsection.title: Elliptical Coordinates and an Integral Relationship

para.sentence: If the boundary conditions in a physical problem relate to the perimeter of an ellipse, then elliptical coordinates are convenient.
These are given by x=c\cosh\xi\cos\eta, y=c\sinh\xi\sin\eta.

The two-dimensional wave equation \frac{{\partial}^{2}V}{{\partial x}^{2}}+\frac{{\partial}^{2}V}{{\partial y}^{ 2}}+k^{2}V=0 then becomes \frac{{\partial}^{2}V}{{\partial\xi}^{2}}+\frac{{\partial}^{2}V}{{\partial\eta }^{2}}+\frac{1}{2}c^{2}k^{2}(\cosh\left(2\xi\right)-\cos\left(2\eta\right))V=0.

The separated solutions V(\xi,\eta)=v(\xi)w(\eta) can be obtained from the modified Mathieu’s equation (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.mM) for v and from Mathieu’s equation (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.Ma) for w , where a is the separation constant and q=\tfrac{1}{4}c^{2}k^{2}.
This leads to integral equations and an integral relation between the solutions of Mathieu’s equation (setting \zeta=\mathrm{i}\xi , z=\eta in(LABEL:eq:MA.DE.PD)).

Let u(\zeta) be a solution of Mathieu’s equation (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.Ma) and K(z,\zeta) be a solution of \frac{{\partial}^{2}K}{{\partial z}^{2}}-\frac{{\partial}^{2}K}{{\partial\zeta }^{2}}=2q\left(\cos\left(2z\right)-\cos\left(2\zeta\right)\right)K.

Also let \mathcal{L} be a curve (possibly improper) such that the quantity K(z,\zeta)\frac{\mathrm{d}u(\zeta)}{\mathrm{d}\zeta}-u(\zeta)\frac{\partial K( z,\zeta)}{\partial\zeta} approaches the same value when \zeta tends to the endpoints of \mathcal{L}.

Then w(z)=\int_{\mathcal{L}}K(z,\zeta)u(\zeta)\mathrm{d}\zeta defines a solution of Mathieu’s equation, provided that (in the case of an improper curve) the integral converges with respect to z uniformly on compact subsets of \mathbb{C}.
Kernels K can be found, for example, by separating solutions of the wave equation in other systems of orthogonal coordinates.
See ( ) .

The general paraboloidal coordinate system is linked with Cartesian coordinates via x_{1}=\tfrac{1}{2}c\left(\cosh\left(2\alpha\right)+\cos\left(2\beta\right)- \cosh\left(2\gamma\right)\right), x_{2}=2c\cosh\alpha\cos\beta\sinh\gamma, x_{3}=2c\sinh\alpha\sin\beta\cosh\gamma, where c is a parameter, 0\leq\alpha<\infty , -\pi<\beta\leq\pi , and 0\leq\gamma<\infty.

When the Helmholtz equation \nabla^{2}V+k^{2}V=0 is separated in this system, each of the separated equations can be reduced to the Whittaker–Hill equation (LABEL:eq:MA.WH.W0), in which A,B areseparation constants.
Two conditions are used to determine A,B.
The first is the 2\pi -periodicity of the solutions; the second can be their asymptotic form.
For further information see ( ) for k^{2}<0 , and ( ) for k^{2}>0.
Mathieu functions occur in practical applications in two main categories: Boundary-values problems arising from solution of the two-dimensional wave equation in elliptical coordinates.
This yields a pair of equations of the form (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.Ma) and (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.mM), and the appropriate solution of (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.Ma) is usually a periodic solution of integer order.
See §LABEL:sec:MA.PA.BP.
Initial-value problems, in which only one equation (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.Ma) or (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.mM) is involved. See §LABEL:sec:MA.PA.SP.
Physical problems involving Mathieu functions include vibrational problems in elliptical coordinates; see (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.CE).
We shall derive solutions tothe uniform, homogeneous, loss-free, and stretched elliptical ring membrane with mass \rho per unit area, and radial tension \tau per unit arc length.

The wave equation \frac{{\partial}^{2}W}{{\partial x}^{2}}+\frac{{\partial}^{2}W}{{\partial y}^{ 2}}-\frac{\rho}{\tau}\frac{{\partial}^{2}W}{{\partial t}^{2}}=0, with W(x,y,t)=e^{\mathrm{i}\omega t}V(x,y) , reduces to (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.WV) with k^{2}=\omega^{2}\rho/{\tau}.
In elliptical coordinates (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.WV) becomes (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.PD).

The separated solutions V_{n}(\xi,\eta) must be 2\pi -periodic in \eta , and have the form V_{n}(\xi,\eta)=\left(c_{n}{\mathrm{M}^{(1)}_{n}}\left(\xi,\sqrt{q}\right)+d_{ n}{\mathrm{M}^{(2)}_{n}}\left(\xi,\sqrt{q}\right)\right)\mathrm{me}_{n}\left( \eta,q\right), where q=\tfrac{1}{4}c^{2}k^{2} and a_{n}(q) or b_{n}(q) is the separation constant; compare ( LABEL:eq:MA.FE.F5), (LABEL:eq:MA.MMF.M11), and (LABEL:eq:MA.MMF.M21).
Here c_{n} and d_{n} are constants.

The boundary conditions for \xi=\xi_{0} (outer clamp) and \xi=\xi_{1} (inner clamp) yield the following equation for q : {\mathrm{M}^{(1)}_{n}}\left(\xi_{0},\sqrt{q}\right){\mathrm{M}^{(2)}_{n}}\left (\xi_{1},\sqrt{q}\right)-{\mathrm{M}^{(1)}_{n}}\left(\xi_{1},\sqrt{q}\right){ \mathrm{M}^{(2)}_{n}}\left(\xi_{0},\sqrt{q}\right)=0.

If the parameters of a physical system vary periodically with time, then the question of stability arises, for example, a mathematical pendulum whose length varies as \cos\left(2\omega t\right).
The equation of motion is given by w^{\prime\prime}(t)+\left(b-f\cos\left(2\omega t\right)\right)w(t)=0, with b , f , and \omega positive constants.
Substituting z=\omega t , a=\ifrac{b}{\omega^{2}} , and 2q=\ifrac{f}{\omega^{2}} , we obtain Mathieu’s standard form (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.Ma).

As \omega runs from 0 to +\infty , with b and f fixed, the point (q,a) moves from \infty to 0 along the ray \mathcal{L} given by the part of the line a=(2b/f)q that lies in the first quadrant of the (q,a) -plane.

Hence from §LABEL:sec:MA.EQ.LX the corresponding Mathieu equation is stable or unstable according as (q,a) is in the intersection of \mathcal{L} with the colored or the uncolored open regions depicted in Figure LABEL:fig:MA.GR.SCP.
In particular, the equation is stable for all sufficiently large values of \omega.
For points (q,a) that are at intersections of \mathcal{L} with the characteristic curves a=a_{n}\left(q\right) or a=b_{n}\left(q\right) , a periodic solution is possible.
However, in response to a small perturbation at least one solution may become unbounded.
